questions.question: Which of the following positions does Sarah Conly, author of "Three Cheers for the Nanny State", make in the article?

choices.answer: Banning large sodas is a good idea.
It is not the government's place to intervene.
Banning fast food is a good idea.
People should make their own decisions about their health.

questions.question: Conly is using the event of New York's Soda Ban to bring light to which of the following larger issues?

choices.answer: Food industries needing stronger regulations.
America's freedoms being taken away.
Nanny states needing more government support in making decisions.
Humans not being capable of making rational decisions and needing help.

questions.question: Author Sarah Conly and the New York Times are both reliable sources of information.

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: Does Conly provide relevant evidence as to WHY soda is bad for us and should be regulated?

choices.answer: Yes, in all body paragraphs.
No, because it would not support her overall message to readers.
No, and she should have.
Yes, and it greatly strengthened her claim.

questions.question: Which persuasive technique does Conly NOT use?

choices.answer: Questioning
Research
Statistics
Real-Life Examples

questions.question: Does Conly's counterclaim help strengthen her claim that the government should assist the public in making decisions?

choices.answer: No, because it does not talk about why soda is bad.
Yes, because it talks about why soda is bad.
Yes, because it proves that humans do not always think clearly.
There is no counterclaim.

questions.question: Conlyâ€™s tone comes across as considerate yet concerned.

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: True or False: At times, Conly's tone appears conversational and informal.

choices.answer: True- Conly uses lots of rhetorical questions.
True- Conly uses a lot of slang.
False- Conly does not address the reader specifically.
False- Conly simply states her ideas in a technical manner.

questions.question: Does Conly have any logical fallacies that weaken her argument?

choices.answer: Yes, but just one.
Yes, several!
No, her logic is very sound.
What is a fallacy?

questions.question: Which organizational structure does Conly use?

choices.answer: Problem and Solution
Cause and Effect
Compare and Contrast
Sequential

questions.question: How would you rate the overall effectiveness of this article?

choices.answer: THE BEST- All parts of an argument were successfully used.
THE WORST- No parts of an argument were successfully used.
AVERAGE- The logic could use some improvement.
AVERAGE- The claim could use some improvement.
